             <channel>
        <title>New Scientist - Home</title>
        <description>New Scientist - Home</description>
        <link>https://www.newscientist.com</link>
        <image>
        <title>New Scientist - Home</title>

                <sy:updateFrequency>1</sy:updateFrequency>
                        <item>
                    <title>To solve a crisis of empathy we must first decide what it is</title>
                    <link>
        https://www.newscientist.com/article/mg23030733-300-to-solve-a-crisis-of-empathy-we-must-first-decide-what-it-is/                    </link>
                    <pubDate>Wed, 11 May 2016 18:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
                                        <description>
                    The empathy crisis, as identified by the pope and others, is too loosely defined for us to do anything about it, if it exists at all                    </description>
                    <guid isPermaLink="false">http://mg23030733.300</guid>
                                                </item>
                                                    <item>
                    <title>Embryo protein may warn before miscarriage and pre-eclampsia</title>
                    <link>
        https://www.newscientist.com/article/2088033-embryo-protein-may-warn-before-miscarriage-and-pre-eclampsia/                    </link>
                    <pubDate>Thu, 12 May 2016 23:01:58 +0000</pubDate>
                                        <description>
                    A protein that seems to help embryos implant into their mother's womb may one day warn doctors that a women might encounter problems in pregnancy                    </description>
                    <guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.newscientist.com/?post_type=article&p=2088033</guid>
                                                </item>
                                                    <item>
                    <title>Computer glitch has led to incorrect advice on statins</title>
                    <link>
        https://www.newscientist.com/article/2087983-computer-glitch-has-led-to-incorrect-advice-on-statins/                    </link>
                    <pubDate>Thu, 12 May 2016 16:35:14 +0000</pubDate>
                                        <description>
                    A software error means that around a third of UK family doctors have been miscalculating whether people need medicine to avoid a heart attack since 2009                    </description>
                    <guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.newscientist.com/?post_type=article&p=2087983</guid>
                                                </item>
                                                    <item>
                    <title>Building blocks of life’s first self-replicator recreated in lab</title>
                    <link>
        https://www.newscientist.com/article/2088006-building-blocks-of-lifes-first-self-replicator-recreated-in-lab/                    </link>
                    <pubDate>Thu, 12 May 2016 17:00:33 +0000</pubDate>
                    		<category><![CDATA[biology]]></category>
		<category><![CDATA[evolution]]></category>
                    <description>
                    RNA molecules are thought to be some of the earliest self-replicators that led to life. Now their building blocks have been made to self-assemble in a lab                    </description>
                    <guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.newscientist.com/?post_type=article&p=2088006</guid>
                                                </item>
                                                    <item>
                    <title>Unnamed dwarf planet may be third largest in the solar system</title>
                    <link>
        https://www.newscientist.com/article/2087989-unnamed-dwarf-planet-may-be-third-largest-in-the-solar-system/                    </link>
                    <pubDate>Thu, 12 May 2016 17:39:50 +0000</pubDate>
                    		<category><![CDATA[solar system]]></category>
		<category><![CDATA[space]]></category>
                    <description>
                    A body known only as 2007 OR10 has been given a boost by recent space telescope observations that peg it smaller than only Pluto and Eris                    </description>
                    <guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.newscientist.com/?post_type=article&p=2087989</guid>
                                                </item>
                                                    <item>
                    <title>Earlier ice melt in the Arctic cuts survival of birds in Africa</title>
                    <link>
        https://www.newscientist.com/article/2087982-earlier-ice-melt-in-the-arctic-cuts-survival-of-birds-in-africa/                    </link>
                    <pubDate>Thu, 12 May 2016 17:00:35 +0000</pubDate>
                                        <description>
                    Red knots are one of many animals shrinking in the face of climate change. This downsizing affects their feeding ability and means fewer survive                    </description>
                    <guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.newscientist.com/?post_type=article&p=2087982</guid>
                                                </item>
                                                    <item>
                    <title>How sharing other people’s feelings can make you sick</title>
                    <link>
        https://www.newscientist.com/article/mg23030732-900-how-sharing-other-peoples-feelings-can-make-you-sick/                    </link>
                    <pubDate>Wed, 11 May 2016 17:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
                                        <description>
                    Everyone says we need more empathy – but too much of it can burn you out. Mind training lessons from monks and psychopaths could help us care without crumbling                    </description>
                    <guid isPermaLink="false">http://mg23030732.900</guid>
                                                </item>
                                                    <item>
                    <title>Got dandruff? The bacteria living on your head might be to blame</title>
                    <link>
        https://www.newscientist.com/article/2087955-got-dandruff-the-bacteria-living-on-your-head-might-be-to-blame/                    </link>
                    <pubDate>Thu, 12 May 2016 13:00:08 +0000</pubDate>
                    		<category><![CDATA[biology]]></category>
		<category><![CDATA[health]]></category>
                    <description>
                    Until now, we’ve been blaming a fungus, but it turns out that too much Staphylococcus in your scalp’s ecosystem could be the cause of flaky dead skin                    </description>
                    <guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.newscientist.com/?post_type=article&p=2087955</guid>
                                                </item>
                                                    <item>
                    <title>Old Scientist: How computers got everywhere</title>
                    <link>
        https://www.newscientist.com/article/2087939-old-scientist-how-computers-got-everywhere/                    </link>
                    <pubDate>Thu, 12 May 2016 10:30:29 +0000</pubDate>
                                        <description>
                    Buds of the future spotted by New Scientist in Mays past, from computer-controlled vehicles to digital media                    </description>
                    <guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.newscientist.com/?post_type=article&p=2087939</guid>
                                                </item>
                                                    <item>
                    <title>High antidepressant use could lead to UK public health disaster</title>
                    <link>
        https://www.newscientist.com/article/2087949-high-antidepressant-use-could-lead-to-uk-public-health-disaster/                    </link>
                    <pubDate>Thu, 12 May 2016 11:34:05 +0000</pubDate>
                                        <description>
                    Use of antidepressants has doubled in the past decade in the UK, and campaigners warn that it could lead to long-term withdrawal and worse mental health                    </description>
                    <guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.newscientist.com/?post_type=article&p=2087949</guid>
                                                </item>
                                                    <item>
                    <title>The impossible barber and other bizarre thought experiments</title>
                    <link>
        https://www.newscientist.com/article/2087688-the-impossible-barber-and-other-bizarre-thought-experiments/                    </link>
                    <pubDate>Wed, 11 May 2016 17:00:27 +0000</pubDate>
                                        <description>
                    How inventing riddles has revealed the flaws in our grasp of reality                    </description>
                    <guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.newscientist.com/?post_type=article&p=2087688</guid>
                                                </item>
                                                    <item>
                    <title>World War Zero brought down mystery civilisation of ‘sea people’</title>
                    <link>
        https://www.newscientist.com/article/2087924-world-war-zero-brought-down-mystery-civilisation-of-sea-people/                    </link>
                    <pubDate>Thu, 12 May 2016 05:00:35 +0000</pubDate>
                                        <description>
                    The Trojan War depicted in Homer's Iliad may have been part of a larger clash of civilisations – one of which has so far gone unrecognised by modern historians

                     </description>
                    <guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.newscientist.com/?post_type=article&p=2087924</guid>
                                                </item>
                                                    <item>
                    <title>Our audience with the Pope revealed how glitz funds medicine</title>
                    <link>
        https://www.newscientist.com/article/mg23030733-100-papal-audience-shows-how-private-cash-is-driving-precision-medicine/                    </link>
                    <pubDate>Wed, 11 May 2016 12:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
                                        <description>
                    A distinguished crowd of philanthropists at the Vatican heard a well-crafted appeal for funds to boost regenerative medicine. Sumit Paul-Choudhury was there                    </description>
                    <guid isPermaLink="false">http://mg23030733.100</guid>
                                                </item>
                                                    <item>
                    <title>Let’s not drive blindly into the autonomous car revolution</title>
                    <link>
        https://www.newscientist.com/article/mg23030733-200-lets-not-drive-blindly-into-the-next-transport-revolution/                    </link>
                    <pubDate>Wed, 11 May 2016 12:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
                                        <description>
                    First there was the horseless carriage, now the driverless car. The car revolution of the 20th century holds lessons for the next one                    </description>
                    <guid isPermaLink="false">http://mg23030733.200</guid>
                                                </item>
                                                    <item>
                    <title>Five Pacific islands vanish from sight as sea levels rise</title>
                    <link>
        https://www.newscientist.com/article/2087356-five-pacific-islands-vanish-from-sight-as-sea-levels-rise/                    </link>
                    <pubDate>Mon, 09 May 2016 13:10:17 +0000</pubDate>
                                        <description>
                    Solomon Islands are taking the brunt of sea level rise, with five of them already submerged – a picture of what we can expect elsewhere by the end of the century

                     </description>
                    <guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.newscientist.com/?post_type=article&p=2087356</guid>
                                                </item>
                                                    <item>
                    <title>Matter, energy… knowledge: How to harness physics’ demonic power</title>
                    <link>
        https://www.newscientist.com/article/mg23030730-200-demon-no-more-physics-most-elusive-entity-gives-up-its-secret/                    </link>
                    <pubDate>Wed, 11 May 2016 18:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
                                        <description>
                    Running a brain-twisting thought experiment for real shows that information is a physical thing – so can we now harness the most elusive entity in the cosmos?                    </description>
                    <guid isPermaLink="false">http://mg23030730.200</guid>
                                                </item>
                                                    <item>
                    <title>Shooting stars show Earth had oxygen eons before we thought</title>
                    <link>
        https://www.newscientist.com/article/2087917-shooting-stars-show-earth-had-oxygen-eons-before-we-thought/                    </link>
                    <pubDate>Wed, 11 May 2016 17:00:54 +0000</pubDate>
                                        <description>
                    Tiny meteorites discovered in Australia show that Earth's air had some oxygen in it at a time when no one thought it did – 2.7 billion years ago                    </description>
                    <guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.newscientist.com/?post_type=article&p=2087917</guid>
                                                </item>
                                                    <item>
                    <title>Do you have a secret? The way you write emails may give it away</title>
                    <link>
        https://www.newscientist.com/article/2087118-do-you-have-a-secret-the-way-you-write-emails-may-give-it-away/                    </link>
                    <pubDate>Thu, 05 May 2016 13:24:07 +0000</pubDate>
                                        <description>
                    The different ways we try to cover up the fact we have something to hide have been revealed by an analysis of 59,000 emails sent by people with secrets                    </description>
                    <guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.newscientist.com/?post_type=article&p=2087118</guid>
                                                </item>
                                                    <item>
                    <title>The perfect heists that involve stealing nothing at all</title>
                    <link>
        https://www.newscientist.com/article/2087863-the-perfect-heists-that-involve-stealing-nothing-at-all/                    </link>
                    <pubDate>Wed, 11 May 2016 15:04:18 +0000</pubDate>
                                        <description>
                    Instead of making off with actual objects, thieves can now just pinch the data that describes them and recreate exact replicas of their own                    </description>
                    <guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.newscientist.com/?post_type=article&p=2087863</guid>
                                                </item>
                                                    <item>
                    <title>This Turing machine should run forever unless maths is wrong</title>
                    <link>
        https://www.newscientist.com/article/2087845-this-turing-machine-should-run-forever-unless-maths-is-wrong/                    </link>
                    <pubDate>Wed, 11 May 2016 14:31:38 +0000</pubDate>
                                        <description>
                    Two researchers have come up with computer programs that will run forever as long as the deep mathematical assumptions they are testing are correct                    </description>
                    <guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.newscientist.com/?post_type=article&p=2087845</guid>
                                                </item>
                                                    <item>
                    <title>Megacities Asia challenges the utopian view of smart cities</title>
                    <link>
        https://www.newscientist.com/article/2087812-megacities-asia-challenges-the-utopian-view-of-smart-cities/                    </link>
                    <pubDate>Wed, 11 May 2016 13:17:17 +0000</pubDate>
                                        <description>
                    An international art show about big cities explores the changing face of urban development, and what we might lose in pursuit of the future                    </description>
                    <guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.newscientist.com/?post_type=article&p=2087812</guid>
                                                </item>
                                                    <item>
                    <title>Silicon Valley cash is flooding into science – but is it useful?</title>
                    <link>
        https://www.newscientist.com/article/mg23030733-000-billionaire-money-is-pouring-into-science-is-it-better-off-for-it/                    </link>
                    <pubDate>Wed, 11 May 2016 12:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
                                        <description>
                    Tech billionaires are falling over themselves to donate to science – as long as they can call the (moon)shots. Not everyone is happy about that                    </description>
                    <guid isPermaLink="false">http://mg23030733.000</guid>
                                                </item>
                                                    <item>
                    <title>London is set for driverless car roll-out – so what comes next?</title>
                    <link>
        https://www.newscientist.com/article/mg23030732-600-london-to-see-fleet-of-driverless-cars-on-public-roads-this-year/                    </link>
                    <pubDate>Wed, 11 May 2016 11:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
                                        <description>
                    What's the difference between a guardian angel and a chauffeur? That's just one of the things you need to know about the robot-on-the-road revolution                    </description>
                    <guid isPermaLink="false">http://mg23030732.600</guid>
                                                </item>
                                                    <item>
                    <title>Super-salty Turkish lakes may hold key to spotting life on Mars</title>
                    <link>
        https://www.newscientist.com/article/2087612-super-salty-turkish-lakes-may-hold-key-to-spotting-life-on-mars/                    </link>
                    <pubDate>Tue, 10 May 2016 15:55:15 +0000</pubDate>
                    		<category><![CDATA[biology]]></category>
		<category><![CDATA[solar system]]></category>
                    <description>
                    A new survey of extreme microbes living in salty and alkaline lakes could yield "fingerprints" that help detect the biological origin of rocks on Mars                    </description>
                    <guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.newscientist.com/?post_type=article&p=2087612</guid>
                                                </item>
                                                    <item>
                    <title>Let’s hope crowdsourcing will reveal the truth about Gaza attack</title>
                    <link>
        https://www.newscientist.com/article/mg23030723-000-crowdsourcing-truth/                    </link>
                    <pubDate>Wed, 04 May 2016 18:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
                                        <description>
                    Social media videos and photos from ordinary citizens can reconstruct what really happened in conflicts where objectivity has become a casualty                    </description>
                    <guid isPermaLink="false">http://mg23030723.000</guid>
                                                </item>
                                                    <item>
                    <title>The walls have eyes: Buildings reveal the conflict they witness</title>
                    <link>
        https://www.newscientist.com/article/mg23030720-400-the-walls-have-eyes-buildings-reveal-the-conflict-they-witness/                    </link>
                    <pubDate>Wed, 04 May 2016 18:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
                                        <description>
                    Eyal Weizman is pioneering the art and science of "forensic architecture", to reveal the true extent of state-sponsored violence                    </description>
                    <guid isPermaLink="false">http://mg23030720.400</guid>
                                                </item>
                                                    <item>
                    <title>Kepler doubles exoplanet population with 1284 new planets</title>
                    <link>
        https://www.newscientist.com/article/2087655-kepler-doubles-exoplanet-population-with-1284-new-planets/                    </link>
                    <pubDate>Tue, 10 May 2016 20:16:46 +0000</pubDate>
                    		<category><![CDATA[exoplanet]]></category>
		<category><![CDATA[solar system]]></category>
		<category><![CDATA[space]]></category>
                    <description>
                    The new planet haul is the biggest yet, bringing the number of confirmed worlds outside our solar system over 3200 - and edges us closer to knowing how many stars host other Earths                    </description>
                    <guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.newscientist.com/?post_type=article&p=2087655</guid>
                                                </item>
                                                    <item>
                    <title>Was gravitational wave signal from a gravastar, not black holes?</title>
                    <link>
        https://www.newscientist.com/article/mg23030724-100-was-gravitational-wave-signal-from-a-gravastar-not-black-holes/                    </link>
                    <pubDate>Wed, 04 May 2016 18:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
                                        <description>
                    LIGO’s discovery of gravitational waves was a great achievement, but a new analysis suggests the signal could have come from a rather exotic source                    </description>
                    <guid isPermaLink="false">http://mg23030724.100</guid>
                                                </item>
                                                    <item>
                    <title>Adding rocks to oceans could de-acidify water and save coral</title>
                    <link>
        https://www.newscientist.com/article/2087532-adding-rocks-to-oceans-could-de-acidify-water-and-save-coral/                    </link>
                    <pubDate>Tue, 10 May 2016 12:27:32 +0000</pubDate>
                                        <description>
                    Real world trials of the geoengineering scheme to cut ocean acidification that is harming marine life are planned off the coast of Netherlands                    </description>
                    <guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.newscientist.com/?post_type=article&p=2087532</guid>
                                                </item>
                                                    <item>
                    <title>Goopy dark matter could slow down expansion of the universe</title>
                    <link>
        https://www.newscientist.com/article/2087465-goopy-dark-matter-could-slow-down-expansion-of-the-universe/                    </link>
                    <pubDate>Tue, 10 May 2016 12:00:02 +0000</pubDate>
                                        <description>
                    A speculative form of dark matter could have a surprising effect on the universe's early evolution – making gravitational waves from the big bang easier to see
                    </description>
                    <guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.newscientist.com/?post_type=article&p=2087465</guid>
                                                </item>
                                                    <item>
                    <title>Invisible radar wall in the atmosphere caused by UV from the sun</title>
                    <link>
        https://www.newscientist.com/article/2087445-invisible-radar-wall-in-the-atmosphere-caused-by-uv-from-the-sun/                    </link>
                    <pubDate>Tue, 10 May 2016 08:26:25 +0000</pubDate>
                                        <description>
                    Waves of vibrating electrons, freed by ultraviolet light from the sun, seem to be why radar beams bounce off the upper atmosphere                    </description>
                    <guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.newscientist.com/?post_type=article&p=2087445</guid>
                                                </item>
                                                    <item>
                    <title>Gravitational waves: Your cheat sheet on the find of the decade</title>
                    <link>
        https://www.newscientist.com/article/2087381-gravitational-waves-your-cheat-sheet-on-the-find-of-the-decade/                    </link>
                    <pubDate>Mon, 09 May 2016 15:54:58 +0000</pubDate>
                                        <description>
                    When space-time ripples, what does it ripple into? Find the answers to this and more not-so-dumb questions in our ultimate gravitational-wave primer                    </description>
                    <guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.newscientist.com/?post_type=article&p=2087381</guid>
                                                </item>
                                                    <item>
                    <title>Carnivorous plant conned out of a meal by cunning fly larvae</title>
                    <link>
        https://www.newscientist.com/article/2087352-carnivorous-plant-conned-out-of-a-meal-by-cunning-fly-larvae/                    </link>
                    <pubDate>Mon, 09 May 2016 13:20:34 +0000</pubDate>
                                        <description>
                    It's a fly in the sundew's ointment. A species of fly larvae have adapted to wade unscathed through the plant's deadly juices, to steal the insects it catches                    </description>
                    <guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.newscientist.com/?post_type=article&p=2087352</guid>
                                                </item>
                                                    <item>
                    <title>A fifth of all plants threatened as habitats shrink worldwide</title>
                    <link>
        https://www.newscientist.com/article/2087440-a-fifth-of-all-plants-threatened-as-habitats-shrink-worldwide/                    </link>
                    <pubDate>Mon, 09 May 2016 23:01:42 +0000</pubDate>
                                        <description>
                    Most types of plant communities have had their ranges changed by more than 10 per cent since 2001, with mangroves and coniferous forests taking the brunt                    </description>
                    <guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.newscientist.com/?post_type=article&p=2087440</guid>
                                                </item>
                                                    <item>
                    <title>Making a splash: Let’s hear it for the first underwater band</title>
                    <link>
        https://www.newscientist.com/article/2087380-making-a-splash-lets-hear-it-for-the-first-underwater-band/                    </link>
                    <pubDate>Mon, 09 May 2016 15:28:25 +0000</pubDate>
                                        <description>
                    Sandrine Ceurstemont checks out AquaSonic, the world's first aquatic music ensemble, and discovers that the trick to singing in the bath is not to blow bubbles                    </description>
                    <guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.newscientist.com/?post_type=article&p=2087380</guid>
                                                </item>
                                                    <item>
                    <title>How we found them: Inside a giant gravitational wave detector</title>
                    <link>
        https://www.newscientist.com/article/mg23030720-200-how-we-found-them-inside-a-giant-gravitational-wave-detector/                    </link>
                    <pubDate>Wed, 04 May 2016 18:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
                                        <description>
                    It took decades of work to prove that gravitational waves are real. New Scientist goes inside the story – and the awesome tool that did it, LIGO                    </description>
                    <guid isPermaLink="false">http://mg23030720.200</guid>
                                                </item>
                                                    <item>
                    <title>The Hemsley effect: why we fall for celebrity food advice</title>
                    <link>
        https://www.newscientist.com/article/2087418-the-hemsley-effect-why-we-fall-for-celebrity-food-advice/                    </link>
                    <pubDate>Mon, 09 May 2016 16:00:07 +0000</pubDate>
                                        <description>
                    Faddish diets from insta-food stars like the Hemsley sisters thrive in a world that favours easy explanations over real science, says Anthony Warner                    </description>
                    <guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.newscientist.com/?post_type=article&p=2087418</guid>
                                                </item>
                                                    <item>
                    <title>Smart second skin reduces eye bags and wrinkles – or so it seems</title>
                    <link>
        https://www.newscientist.com/article/2087378-smart-second-skin-reduces-eye-bags-and-wrinkles-or-so-it-seems/                    </link>
                    <pubDate>Mon, 09 May 2016 15:00:57 +0000</pubDate>
                                        <description>
                    An invisible polymer appears to work as ‘Spanx for your face’, reducing sagging and restoring a youthful glow, but some dermatologists are sceptical                    </description>
                    <guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.newscientist.com/?post_type=article&p=2087378</guid>
                                                </item>
                                                    <item>
                    <title>Early Earth’s air may have been thinner than on Everest today</title>
                    <link>
        https://www.newscientist.com/article/2087379-early-earths-air-may-have-been-thinner-than-on-everest-today/                    </link>
                    <pubDate>Mon, 09 May 2016 15:00:13 +0000</pubDate>
                                        <description>
                    Measurements on ancient lava suggest air pressure was once very low, refuting the idea that a thick atmosphere helped warm Earth when sun was less bright                    </description>
                    <guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.newscientist.com/?post_type=article&p=2087379</guid>
                                                </item>
                                                    <item>
                    <title>Facebook must fight for its facial recognition tech in court</title>
                    <link>
        https://www.newscientist.com/article/2087372-facebook-must-fight-for-its-facial-recognition-tech-in-court/                    </link>
                    <pubDate>Mon, 09 May 2016 14:42:33 +0000</pubDate>
                                        <description>
                    A class-action lawsuit that argues Facebook's face-tagging software violates Illinois biometrics laws could have consequences for facial recognition technology                    </description>
                    <guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.newscientist.com/?post_type=article&p=2087372</guid>
                                                </item>
                                                    <item>
                    <title>First global Mercury map shows its hills and valleys in detail</title>
                    <link>
        https://www.newscientist.com/article/2087347-first-global-mercury-map-shows-its-hills-and-valleys-in-detail/                    </link>
                    <pubDate>Mon, 09 May 2016 11:51:17 +0000</pubDate>
                                        <description>
                    The team behind NASA's Messenger mission to Mercury has released the first global topographic map of the planet – just in time for its biggest show of the decade                    </description>
                    <guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.newscientist.com/?post_type=article&p=2087347</guid>
                                                </item>
                                                    <item>
                    <title>How to watch Mercury pass in front of the sun today</title>
                    <link>
        https://www.newscientist.com/article/2087154-how-to-watch-mercury-pass-in-front-of-the-sun-today/                    </link>
                    <pubDate>Fri, 06 May 2016 06:00:32 +0000</pubDate>
                                        <description>
                    You'll need special telescopes to watch the innermost planet transit the sun, an event lasting around seven hours, or you can watch online                    </description>
                    <guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.newscientist.com/?post_type=article&p=2087154</guid>
                                                </item>
                                                    <item>
                    <title>‘Midlife MOTs’ don’t work so why are doctors pushed to do them?</title>
                    <link>
        https://www.newscientist.com/article/2087336-midlife-mots-dont-work-so-why-are-doctors-pushed-to-do-them/                    </link>
                    <pubDate>Mon, 09 May 2016 10:20:13 +0000</pubDate>
                                        <description>
                    Over-40s health checks cost £363 million a year, and may do more harm than good. Why are people in England still being pushed to have them, asks Clare Wilson                    </description>
                    <guid isPermaLink="false">https://www.newscientist.com/?post_type=article&p=2087336</guid>
                                                </item>
                                                    <item>
                    <title>If Google has nothing to hide about NHS data, why so secretive?</title>
                    <link>
        https://www.newscientist.com/article/mg23030722-900-big-data-if-theres-nothing-to-hide-why-be-secretive/                    </link>
                    <pubDate>Wed, 04 May 2016 10:12:00 +0000</pubDate>
                                        <description>
                    Google's subsidiary DeepMind could use our health data to diagnose disease sooner. If it was more open, we might be happier to let it go ahead                    </description>
                    <guid isPermaLink="false">http://mg23030722.900</guid>
                                                </item>
                                                    <item>
                    <title>That’s odd: Quantum entanglement mangles space and time</title>
                    <link>
        https://www.newscientist.com/article/mg23030710-500-thats-odd-quantum-entanglement-mangles-space-and-time/                    </link>
                    <pubDate>Wed, 27 Apr 2016 18:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
                                        <description>
                    Spooky action at a distance – the dislocated effect of the quantum world – is real without a doubt. So the problem must lie in our perception of space and time                    </description>
                    <guid isPermaLink="false">http://mg23030710.500</guid>
                                                </item>
                                        </channel>
</rss>
